item.title: Covid vaccine: We need answers on autumn booster plan, say health leaders
item.description: The government has already promised a Covid booster rollout but it is yet to set out how it will work.

item.title: France regional election: Macron and Le Pen fail to make ground - exit poll
item.description: Early results indicate both parties have failed to make ground in France's regional elections.

item.title: New season tickets go on sale for part-time commuters
item.description: Passengers who travel to work two or three days a week now have the option of a flexible monthly ticket.

item.title: PM's research budget to make UK 'science superpower'
item.description: Boris Johnson says the country will be able to "breathe life into more breakthroughs that transform lives".

item.title: US Navy uses 40,000lb explosive to test warship in 'Full Ship Shock Trial'
item.description: The US Navy conducted a 'Full Ship Shock Trial' against its aircraft carrier, the USS Gerald R. Ford.

item.title: Usain Bolt welcomes newborn twin sons Thunder and Saint Leo
item.description: The Olympic champion and his girlfriend Kasi Bennett announced the births on Instagram.

item.title: Contaminated blood inquiry: The school where dozens of pupils died
item.description: Ex-pupils caught up in the infected blood scandal decades ago will give evidence at an inquiry.

item.title: Covid: Music and comedy venue changes in Wales lockdown easing
item.description: Capacity rules in gig and comedy venues relaxed in a slight lifting on Welsh lockdown restrictions.

item.title: Andy Burnham's anger at Manchester-Scotland travel ban
item.description: Andy Burnham says he will ask the Scottish government for compensation for affected individuals.

item.title: Italy 1-0 Wales: Visitors through to last 16 despite defeat in Rome
item.description: Wales demonstrate huge resolve in defeat against Italy as they cling on with 10 men to progress to the second round of Euro 2020.

item.title: Armenia election: PM Nikol Pashinyan claims victory
item.description: The snap election was called in the wake of the country's defeat in a conflict with Azerbaijan.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Ugandan tests positive for Covid in Japan
item.description: The Ugandan was part of a nine-member squad who were fully vaccinated, reports say.

item.title: US Open: Jon Rahm finishes with back-to-back birdies to claim first major title
item.description: Spain's Jon Rahm claims an incredible first major title as he finishes with back-to-back birdies on a breathless US Open final day at Torrey Pines.

item.title: The papers: Jab hope to save travel and pensions tax threat
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine rollout, foreign travel hopes and possible pension tax changes lead Monday's papers.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Margaret Keenan reflects receiving world's first jab
item.description: Since receiving the world's first Covid-19 vaccine, Ms Keenan has stayed in contact with the nurse who administered it.

item.title: 'I play all the instruments in my Irish music band'
item.description: Caitríona Lagan is a 15-year-old All-Ireland champion musician who plays five instruments.

item.title: South Korea: Swapping Seoul megacity isolation for village life
item.description: Some South Korean families are abandoning Seoul and swapping megacity isolation for rural village life.

item.title: Tankers and Transit vans sculpted into steel forests
item.description: Dan Rawlings has transformed a petrol lorry into a woodland sculpture with an environmental message.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Can this athletes' village keep out Covid?
item.description: Thousands of athletes will be living together for several weeks - how will they be kept safe?

item.title: Dál Riata Channel: First all-female relay team swim 'perilous' waterway
item.description: The group swam from Scotland to NI in just over eight hours, after abandoning a first attempt.

item.title: ICYMI: Birds, planes and automobiles
item.description: Brooklyn ducks, a Brittany bird-man, and a race with a difference - some of the stories you might have missed this week.

item.title: Cummings revelations beyond The Thick of It, says Capaldi
item.description: Peter Capaldi says his famously abrasive character wouldn't fit into the current government landscape.

item.title: The Lazarus heist: How North Korea almost pulled off a billion-dollar hack
item.description: In 2016 North Korean hackers planned a $1bn raid on Bangladesh's national bank and came within an inch of success. But how did they do it?

item.title: Italy 1-0 Wales: The Euro 2020 loss in Rome which felt like a win for Wales
item.description: Wales celebrate one of their greatest defeats, a loss in Rome which takes them to the knockout stage of Euro 2020, where "the real stuff starts".

item.title: Joe Biden: My surprise claim to be the US president's English cousin
item.description: Paul Harris has records that show a link to the president via recently discovered English ancestors.

item.title: Nottingham Castle: How do you market a missing medieval castle?
item.description: Can a £30m refurbishment make up for the fact Nottingham's movie star castle is long gone?

item.title: French court dog helps soothe anxious victims of crime
item.description: How one Labrador has helped the victims of violent crime in southern France.

item.title: Birtukan Mideksa: Ethiopia's electoral board chairperson
item.description: Birtukan Mideksa, a former opposition leader who went into exile in the US, says "shortfalls are inevitable".

item.title: K-wave: How fans are supporting their favourite idols
item.description: From buying billboard space to food trucks, here's how fans of Korean pop culture support their idols.

item.title: Covid: Why has the Delta variant spread so quickly in UK?
item.description: It is now the dominant strain in the UK - but the rest of the world may well follow suit.

item.title: 'War on Terror': Are big military deployments over?
item.description: Twenty years on from the "War on Terror", is it the end of big military deployments to warzones?

item.title: Return to the island where eagles watch you brush your teeth
item.description: Six months after Alex and Buffy moved to the Isle of Rum without visiting it, how has island life worked out?

item.title: TV reunions: Why we're rarely 'on a break' from our favourite shows
item.description: High-profile TV reunions have never been more popular - but why now and what makes one successful?

item.title: NZ edge gripping third day against India in World Test Championship final
item.description: New Zealand wrestle the initiative from India on a fascinating third day of the World Test Championship final in Southampton.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: GB name Laura and Jason Kenny in 26-strong cycling squad
item.description: Multiple Olympic champions Laura and Jason Kenny will lead the GB cycling team at this summer's Tokyo Games.

item.title: Euro 2020: Wales in last 16 despite being beaten by Italy in Rome
item.description: Wales demonstrate great resolve in their 1-0 defeat against Italy as they cling on with 10 men for a result which is enough to secure their place in the second round of Euro 2020.

item.title: Euro 2020: Four brilliant goals as Switzerland beat Turkey 3-1 in Baku
item.description: Watch highlights as Switzerland give themselves a strong chance of qualifying for the last 16 of Euro 2020 as one of the best third-placed sides by beating Turkey 3-1 and finishing with four points.

item.title: Back-to-back birdies put Jon Rahm into US Open lead
item.description: Spain's Jon Rahm takes the lead in the US Open with back-to-back birdies on the 17th and 18th holes.

item.title: 'Shake that tree' - Mackenzie Hughes' ball gets stuck in branches at US Open
item.description: Mackenzie Hughes' ball gets stuck in a tree at US Open scuppering the Canadian's chances on he final day.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: What are the social distancing rules and when could they end?
item.description: Will we still need to be socially distanced through the summer? A social distancing review is advising the government.

item.title: Can we dance outside at our wedding? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over 40s in England and Scotland can have their second dose after eight weeks instead of 12.

item.title: What are the rules for pubs, restaurants, festivals and gigs?
item.description: The lifting of restrictions is being delayed, which could affect planned events

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Coronavirus restrictions are staying in place because of concerns about the Delta variant.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Ros Atkins On… How the Delta variant took hold in the UK
item.description: Ros Atkins traces back the story of the Delta variant and how it delayed the UK’s reopening plans.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: Covid: What are the care home visiting rules?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to people who want to go to see their loved ones.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 42 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: Covid: What do over-18s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now available for younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go... and who with?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: Coronavirus G7: Could a billion more vaccines for poorer countries make a difference?
item.description: How much difference could the G7 offer of a billion vaccines make to tackling the pandemic?

item.title: Covid: Is there a limit to how much worse variants can get?
item.description: The coronavirus has changed and changed again, getting more transmissible each time.

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself from Covid now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Lockdown easing: Four numbers to look for ahead of the 21 June decision
item.description: The key numbers that offer clues as to whether "freedom day" will proceed as planned on 21 June.

item.title: Living with obesity: The people who are hard-wired to store fat
item.description: Specialist health professionals say obesity should be regarded as a complex illness, and people with the condition shouldn't be blamed for it.

item.title: ‘I got PTSD after witnessing my daughter’s birth’
item.description: After the distressing birth of his daughter, Elliott Rae struggled with post traumatic stress disorder.

item.title: 'I was humiliated': The continuing trauma of South Korea's spy cam victims
item.description: Survivors have faced threats and bullying from police when seeking justice, says a new rights report.

item.title: 'Huntington's disease won't stop me having a baby'
item.description: Heather and her husband are going to have a baby, even though Heather's time with the child will be limited.

item.title: 'The 80s song that brought my lost memory back after 10 years'
item.description: A car crash erased Thomas's memory - 10 years later, a 1980s pop song triggered six flashbacks.
